Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon His Trustworthy Messenger, and upon his pure family and rightly guided companions, and those who follow them in goodness until the Day of Judgment... To proceed:
One of the greatest acts of closeness and most majestic acts of obedience is gaining understanding (Fiqh) in religion. Therefore, Allah Almighty encouraged it in His Noble Book, saying: {And it is not for the believers to go forth [to battle] all at once. For there should separate from every division of them a group [remaining] to obtain understanding in the religion and warn their people when they return to them that they might be cautious}. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, praised those who gain understanding in religion and clarified that Allah intended good for them when He guided them towards this noble goal, saying, peace and blessings be upon him: «Whomever Allah wills good for, He gives him understanding in the religion» Agreed upon.
Thus, the virtue of understanding religion over all other sciences becomes clear. Part of understanding religion is enlightening people about their religious matters, warning them against the misleading paths of desires and slippery slopes of seduction, and taking their hands towards the path of truth and correctness.
There is no chapter of Fiqh except that you find people have some Sharia violations in it. Among this is what concerns oaths. And Protect Your Oaths
We will talk under the shade of this noble divine directive about the oath, its rulings, its expiation, and the violations related to it in four sections as follows:
- Section One: The Oath.
- Section Two: Types of Oaths.
- Section Three: Rulings of Oaths.
- Section Four: Expiation of Oaths.

text:
Section One: The Oath

Introduction:
The oath is a legitimate means of proving a right, known since ancient times. Its forms and methods of performance varied in societies according to beliefs, religions, and ideas. It was prevalent among the Arabs in the Pre-Islamic era (Jahiliyyah); so the Wise Lawgiver affirmed it in a way consistent with the sound creed far from polytheism (Shirk). The oath has remained in laws and regulations until our present time, despite the variation of beliefs and the prevalence of atheistic and materialistic doctrines.
I will discuss it in five requirements:
- Requirement One: Definition of the Oath - Its meanings - Reason for its naming.
- Requirement Two: Legitimacy of the Oath - Its ruling - Its conditions.
- Requirement Three: Description of the Oath - Ruling of swearing by other than Allah - Forms of swearing by other than Allah.
- Requirement Four: The command to protect oaths, and the warning against false swearing.
- Requirement Five: Formulas of oaths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, which they used to swear by.

text:
Requirement One: Definition of the Oath - Its meanings - Reason for its naming

First: Definition of the Oath:
Al-Yamin (The Oath) linguistically: Its origin is the right hand, and its plural is Ayman and Aymun (1). From it is His saying Almighty: {And what is that in your right hand (Bi-Yaminika), O Moses?} (2).
Among its meanings:
(a) Strength (3), from it is His saying Almighty: {We would have seized him by the right hand (Bil-Yamin)} (4).
(b) Direction (5), from it is His saying Almighty: {(About) on the right (Al-Yamin) and on the left, in separate groups} (6).
(c) Swearing (Half), Oath (Qasam), and Covenant (Ahd) (7), from it is His saying Almighty: {And they swore by Allah their strongest oaths (Aymanihim)...} (8). And His saying Almighty: {And if they break their oaths (Aymanahum) after their agreement...} (9).
The Oath in Sharia: "It is the confirmation of a thing by mentioning a name or attribute of Allah". This is the most concise definition... and the closest (10).

Second: Reason for its naming:
Swearing was called Yamin (Right Hand): Because when they swore an alliance, each one of them would strike his right hand (Yamin) on the right hand of his companion, so swearing was metaphorically called Yamin (11).
- And it was said: Because the right hand's nature is preserving things, so swearing was called that to preserve the sworn matter, and the sworn matter was called Yamin due to its connection with it (12).
- And it was said: Because swearing is strengthened by the oath (Qasam) (13).
- And it was said: Because it provides strength for the sworn matter, whether doing or leaving it (14).

Requirement Two: Legitimacy of the Oath - Its ruling - Its conditions

First: Legitimacy of the Oath:
The basis for its legitimacy and the establishment of its ruling is the Book, the Sunnah, and Consensus.
As for the Book, it is the saying of Allah Glory be to Him and Most High: {Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths, but He will impose blame upon you for [breaking] what you intended of oaths...} (1). And His saying Almighty: {And do not break oaths after their confirmation...} (2).
Allah commanded His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to swear in three places:
- He Almighty said: {And they ask you, "Is it true?" Say, "Yes, by my Lord, indeed it is truth, and you will not cause failure [to Allah]"} (3).
- And He Glory be to Him said: {Say, "Yes, by my Lord, it will surely come to you"} (4).
- And He Glory be to Him said: {Say, "Yes, by my Lord, you will surely be resurrected"} (5).
As for the Sunnah, it is the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "By Allah, if Allah wills, I do not swear an oath and then see something else better than it, except that I do what is better and expiate for it" (6).
The most frequent oath of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was "And the Turner of hearts - and the Changer of hearts - and by the One in Whose Hand is my soul" as will come later.
- The oath may be subject to the five rulings, so its ruling becomes the ruling of what it leads to: Obligation, Prohibition, Recommendation, Dislike, or Permissibility.
The Ummah agreed on the legitimacy of the oath, the establishment of its ruling, and its original placement for emphasizing the sworn matter (7).

Second: Dislike of excessive swearing:
The principle is not to swear excessively, due to His saying Almighty: {And protect your oaths...} (1). It was said: He meant by it leaving swearing. i.e., do not swear. And it was said - which is the more correct view: He meant by it if you swear, do not break the oath (2).
Excessive swearing by Allah Almighty is disliked; due to His saying Almighty: {And do not obey every worthless habitual swearer} (3). This is a dispraise of him which implies the dislike of his action. If it does not reach the limit of excess, it is not disliked unless accompanied by what necessitates its dislike (4).

Third: Pillar of the Judicial Oath and its conditions:
The jurists agreed on stipulating six conditions for the Judicial Oath, which are:
1 - That the swearer be accountable (Mukallaf) (adult, sane, choosing freely). So a child and a madman do not swear, and the oath of a sleeper and coerced person is not considered.
2 - That the defendant denies the plaintiff's right. If he acknowledges, there is no need for swearing.
3 - That the opponent requests the oath from the judge or the judge directs it to the swearer.
4 - That the oath be personal, so swearing by proxy is not accepted because it relates to the swearer's liability and religion. So the agent or the guardian of a minor does not swear, and the matter is paused until he reaches puberty.
5 - That it not be in rights purely for Allah Almighty like Hudud (prescribed punishments) and Qisas (retribution).
6 - That it be in rights where acknowledgement is permissible. So the oath is not permissible in rights where acknowledgement is not permissible. Thus, the agent, executor, and guardian do not swear; because their acknowledgement against others is not valid (5).
Its pillar:
- The wording used in it. (6)

Requirement Three: Description of the Oath - Ruling of swearing by other than Allah - Forms of swearing by other than Allah

First: Description of the Oath:
The oath is only by a name of Allah Almighty's names, or an attribute of His attributes Glory be to Him, whether it is from the Attributes of Essence or the Attributes of Actions.
The evidences for swearing by the name of Allah Almighty are apparent; among them is the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever has to take an oath should swear by Allah or remain silent" (1). And in Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi with the wording: "or keep quiet" (2). And in a narration by Muslim: "Whoever has to take an oath, let him not swear except by Allah" (3).
Imam Al-Nawawi said - in his explanation of the previous Hadith -: "In the Hadith is the permissibility of swearing by Allah Almighty and all His attributes, and this is agreed upon" (4).
As for swearing by Attributes of Action; it is due to his swearing, peace and blessings be upon him, by the Turner of hearts (Muqallib al-Qulub), and by the Changer of hearts (Musarrif al-Qulub). In Sahih Al-Bukhari from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: "The oath of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to be 'No, and the Turner of hearts'" (5). And in Sunan Ibn Majah "and the Changer of hearts" (6).
Al-Hafiz said in Al-Fath: "Qadi Abu Bakr bin Al-Arabi said: In the Hadith - referring to the Hadith 'No, and the Turner of hearts' - is the permissibility of swearing by Allah's actions if He is described by them and His name is not mentioned (7)".
As for swearing by Attributes of Essence, it is due to what Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Nasa'i narrated from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When Allah created Paradise, He sent Gabriel and said: Look at it and at what I have prepared for its people in it. So he looked at it, then returned and said: No, by Your Might (Izzatika), no one hears of it except that he enters it" (8).

Al-Bukhari titled a chapter in his Sahih - Chapter: Swearing by Allah's Might, Attributes, and Words - and cited Hadiths in it: Among them the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say: "I seek refuge in Your Might". And the Hadith of Abu Huraira from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "A man remains between Paradise and Hell; so he says: O Lord, turn my face away from the Fire, no, by Your Might, I ask You for nothing else" (1).
In the previous Hadiths and their likes is the permissibility of swearing by Allah Almighty's attributes like Might and similar ones such as Power, Majesty, Pride, and Greatness.

Second: Ruling of swearing by other than Allah:
Swearing by other than Allah is not permissible. Prohibition of it has been reported and that it is Shirk. In Sunan Abu Dawood from the Hadith of Ibn Umar - may Allah be pleased with them both, said: I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Whoever swears by other than Allah has committed Shirk" (2). And in the narration of Al-Tirmidhi: "Has committed Kufr (disbelief) or Shirk" (3).
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: "The expression with his saying 'has committed Kufr or Shirk' is for exaggeration in deterring and being strict about that" (4).
Ibn Abd al-Barr said: "Scholars agreed that the oath by other than Allah is disliked and forbidden, no one is permitted to swear by it" (5).
- This type of Shirk: is called Verbal Shirk, and it is Minor Shirk, like swearing by fathers, the Kaaba, Trust (Amanah)... etc.
The wisdom behind the prohibition of swearing by other than Allah is "that swearing by something implies glorifying it, and true greatness belongs only to Allah alone, so no one else should be likened to Him" (6). "And because whoever swears by other than Allah has glorified other than Allah with a glorification resembling the glorification of the Lord Blessed and Exalted. Therefore, it was called Shirk because he associated other than Allah with Allah Almighty in glorifying Him by swearing by him..." (7)

Third: Forms of swearing by other than Allah:
The forms of swearing by other than Allah have multiplied in ancient and modern times, and people have taken them lightly, indifferent to the deterrent texts reported regarding them. I will mention a part of these forms despite their abundance and multiplicity, but the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, encompasses them: "Every oath sworn by other than Allah is Shirk" (1).
1) Swearing by Fathers and Mothers: It is the oath of the polytheists in Jahiliyyah, for Quraysh used to swear by their fathers. Prohibition of it has been reported in our religion. In Al-Bukhari and Muslim from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, caught up with Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, while he was traveling in a group - swearing by his father - so he said: "Verily Allah forbids you from swearing by your fathers... (2)". Umar said: By Allah, I have not sworn by it since I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioning [the prohibition] nor narrating it [from others]. Meaning: I did not swear by it nor did I narrate that from others. And in Sunan Abu Dawood from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not swear by your fathers nor by your mothers... (3)"
2) Swearing by Idols (Andad) and Tyrants (Tawaghit): Due to the Hadith of Abdul Rahman bin Samra, may Allah be pleased with him - that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not swear by Tawaghi..." (4) And in Al-Nasa'i "nor by Tawaghit" (5). Tawaghi is the plural of Taghiya, which are idols, named by the verbal noun because of the disbelievers' tyranny in worshipping them because it is the cause of their tyranny and disbelief (6). And in Sunan Abu Dawood from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not swear by your fathers, nor by your mothers, nor by idols, and do not swear except by Allah, and do not swear unless you are truthful" (7).

text:
Requirement Four: The command to protect oaths - and the warning against false swearing

First: The command to protect oaths:
Allah Almighty commanded the protection of oaths, saying: {And protect your oaths...}. Imam Al-Baghawi said: "He meant by it if you swear, do not break the oath, so the meaning is preserving the oath from breaking (Hinth)..." (1).
Imam Al-Qurtubi said: The meaning is: "Do not swear frequently by Allah" (2).
Allah dispraised those who swear frequently, saying: {And do not obey every worthless habitual swearer}. This is a dispraise of him which implies the dislike of his action. Al-Shawkani said - in the interpretation of the verse: - "One who swears frequently falsely. The Arabs in Jahiliyyah used to praise themselves for few oaths, until one of them said: Few oaths, keeper of his oath ** And if an oath comes from him, it is truthful (3)".
Allah explained in His Book that among the characteristics of hypocrites is frequent false swearing. The Almighty said regarding them: {They swear by Allah to you to please you. But Allah and His Messenger are more worthy for them to satisfy, if they were believers} (4).
In Al-Bukhari and Muslim from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masoud - may Allah be pleased with him - said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked: Which people are best? He said: "My generation, then those who follow them, then those who follow them, then there will come a people whose testimony precedes their oath, and whose oath precedes their testimony" (5).
Imam Al-Nawawi said: "This is a dispraise for one who testifies and swears along with his testimony" (6).
Imam Al-Tahawi said: "Meaning they swear frequently in everything until it becomes a habit for them, so one of them swears where an oath is not required from him and before he is asked to swear" (7).

The Piety of the Companions regarding swearing by other than Allah and their protection of their oaths:
Ibn Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: To swear by Allah falsely is more beloved to me than to swear by other than Allah truthfully. The like of his saying was reported from Ibn Umar (1) and Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said, commenting on Ibn Masoud's words: "Because the good deed of Tawhid is greater than the good deed of truthfulness, and the sin of lying is easier than the sin of Shirk. Allah Almighty said: {Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills} (2).
When the prohibition from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding swearing by fathers reached the Commander of the Faithful Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "By Allah, I have not sworn by them since I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioning [the prohibition] nor narrating it" (3).
When Umar heard Ibn Al-Zubayr swearing by the Kaaba, he said: "If I knew that you thought about it before swearing, I would have punished you. Swear by Allah then sin or be righteous" (4).
It was narrated from Jubayr bin Mut'im, may Allah be pleased with him, that he ransomed his oath with ten thousand Dirhams, then said: "By the Lord of this Mosque, if I swore, I swore truthfully, but it is something I ransomed my oath with" (5).
Al-Ash'ath bin Qais said: "I bought my oath once for seventy thousand" (6).
Thus was the piety of those after the Companions from the Followers and others in preserving their oaths. Amir Al-Sha'bi - may Allah have mercy on him - said: "To swear by Allah and break the oath is more beloved to me than to swear by other than Him and fulfill it" (7).
Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i - may Allah have mercy on him - said: "Our companions (our Sheikhs) used to forbid us, and it was reported with the word 'beat us', while we were boys, from swearing by Testimony and Covenant". In this is the desire to train the young on obeying their Lord and forbidding them from what harms them (8).
It was reported from Al-Shafi'i that he said: "I never swore by Allah, neither truthfully nor falsely".

Second: - Warning against False Swearing:
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, warned against false swearing. In Al-Mu'jam Al-Tabarani from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah, exalted is His mention, permitted me to speak about a rooster whose legs have pierced the earth and whose neck is bent under the Throne, saying: Glory be to You, how great You are our Lord. He replies to it: He does not know that who swore by Me falsely" (1).
False swearing is a characteristic of hypocrisy. The Almighty said - narrating their state -: {And they swear to untruth while they know} (2). He described them with this description in many verses of the Holy Quran. The Almighty said: {They swear by Allah to you to please you. But Allah and His Messenger are more worthy for them to satisfy, if they were believers} (3). And He Almighty said: {And they swear by Allah that they are from among you while they are not from among you; but they are a people who are afraid} (4).
The sin of the false oath increases when it relates to a human right. In Al-Bukhari, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever swears a false oath to misappropriate the wealth of a Muslim man - or he said his brother - will meet Allah Almighty while He is angry with him" (5). So the Muslim must beware of false oaths, and seek truthfulness in his oath, for Allah has magnified the one who swears by Him falsely. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Swear by Allah, be righteous, and speak the truth, for Allah loves to be sworn by" (6).

Requirement Five: Formulas of oaths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, which they used to swear by

First: Oaths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, which he used to swear by:
The oath of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, which he used to swear by and use frequently was:
(a) Wallahi (By Allah): In Sahih Al-Bukhari from the Hadith of the Mother of Believers Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "O Nation of Muhammad, by Allah, if you knew what I know, you would weep much and laugh little" (1). And due to what Al-Tirmidhi narrated from Abdullah bin Adi bin Hamra' who said: "I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, standing on Al-Hazwarah (2) saying: "By Allah, you are the best of Allah's land and the most beloved of Allah's land to Allah, and were it not that I was expelled from you, I would not have left" (3).
(b) Wa-alladhi nafsi bi-yadihi (By the One in Whose Hand is my soul): Due to what Al-Bukhari narrated from Jabir bin Samura from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When Caesar perishes, there will be no Caesar after him, and when Khosrow perishes, there will be no Khosrow after him. And by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, you will surely spend their treasures in the path of Allah" (4).
This oath was reported from him, peace and blessings be upon him, with several wordings, including: "By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Muhammad", and some starting with the phrase "No, and by the One in Whose Hand is my soul", and some with the phrase "Ama (Behold/Truly) and by the One in Whose Hand is my soul", and some with the phrase "Wa-aymu (By) the One in Whose Hand is my soul", and all are wordings established in the Sahih (5). And in Abu Dawood with the wording: "By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Abu Al-Qasim" (6).

Second: Oaths of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them:
The oaths of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, were like the oaths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, for they used to swear like his swearing and emulate him, peace and blessings be upon him. Examples of that include:
(a) Wallahi (By Allah): It was their most frequent oath, due to the Hadith of the Bedouin who came asking about Islam and in it he said "By Allah, I will not increase upon this nor decrease. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: He has succeeded if he is truthful" (4).

Section Two: Types of Oaths
Requirement One: The Vain Oath (Yamin al-Laghw) - Its nature - Its ruling.
Requirement Two: The Contracted Oath (Al-Yamin Al-Mun'aqidah) - Its nature - Its ruling.

text:
Requirement One: The Vain Oath (Yamin al-Laghw) - Its nature - Its ruling
The Vain Oath:
(First) Meaning of Laghw:
Al-Raghib Al-Asfahani said: "It is originally speech that is not considered, and what is meant by it in oaths is what is uttered without thought, so it runs the course of Laga which is the sound of sparrows and similar birds" (1).
There was disagreement in its interpretation on several opinions:
The most famous: which is the school of the majority of scholars, is that it is a man's speech 'No by Allah' and 'Yes by Allah' without intending an oath. Due to what Abu Dawood narrated in his Sunan from Ibrahim Al-Sa'igh who said: I asked Ata about Laghw in the oath? He said: - Aisha said - The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It is a man's speech 'No by Allah' and 'Yes by Allah'" (2). The Hadith was reported from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, as Mawquf (stopped at companion), as in Al-Bukhari, and Marfu' (raised to Prophet) as in... Sahih Ibn Hibban.
(Second) Its ruling:
There is no expiation (Kaffarah) for it and no blame for it. Due to His saying Almighty: {Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths...} (3).
Al-Shawkani said - in the interpretation of this verse -: "And in the verse is evidence that Allah does not hold the swearer accountable for Vain Oaths, and no expiation is obligatory for them" (4).
Imam Ibn Qudamah said: "And most people of knowledge are of the view that the Vain Oath has no expiation. And Ibn Abd al-Barr said: The Muslims agreed on this" (5).

Requirement Two: The Contracted Oath (Al-Yamin Al-Mun'aqidah) - Its nature - Its ruling
The Contracted Oath:
(First) Its nature:
The Contracted Oath (Al-Mun'aqidah): Derived from 'Aqd (tying/contracting), and it is the heart's determination regarding the future not to do something then doing it, or to surely do something then not doing it (1).
(Second): Its ruling:
It is obligatory to fulfill what was sworn upon, and if he breaks the oath (Hinth), expiation is obligatory.
Allah Almighty said: {Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths, but He will impose blame upon you for what your hearts have earned. And Allah is Forgiving and Forbearing} (2).
And He Almighty said: {Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths, but He will impose blame upon you for [breaking] what you intended of oaths...} (3).
And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever swears an oath and sees something else better than it, let him do what is better and expiate for his oath" (4).
Ibn Abd al-Barr said: "The oath that has expiation by the consensus of Muslims is that which is regarding future actions" (5).

Requirement Three: The False Oath (Al-Yamin Al-Ghamus) - Its nature - Reason for its naming - Its ruling
The False Oath (Al-Yamin Al-Ghamus): Also called the Patient Oath (Al-Yamin Al-Sabirah).
(First) Its nature:
Al-Yamin Al-Ghamus: Al-Manawi said: Al-Yamin Al-Ghamus is swearing falsely regarding a past action or omission (1).
Its explanation was reported from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Hadith narrated by Al-Bukhari, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Nasa'i from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The major sins are associating partners with Allah, disobeying parents, and the Ghamus Oath". And in a narration that a Bedouin came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, what are the major sins? He said: "Associating partners with Allah." He said: Then what? He said: "The Ghamus Oath?" I said: And what is the Ghamus Oath? He said: "The one who appropriates the wealth of a Muslim man by an oath in which he is lying" (2).
And in Mustadrak Al-Hakim from the Hadith of Ibn Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: We used to count among the sins that have no expiation the Ghamus Oath. It was said: And what is the Ghamus Oath? He said: A man appropriating with his oath the wealth of a man" (3).
(Second) Reason for its naming:
Al-Hafiz said: It was named so because it dips (Taghmis) its owner in sin, then in Fire. It was said: The origin of that is that when they wanted to make a covenant, they would bring a bowl and put perfume or blood or ashes in it, then swear when they dip their hands in it to complete by that the intended confirmation of what they wanted. So that oath was called Ghamusa when its owner betrayed because he went to the extreme in breaking the covenant, as if it is, based on this, taken from the dipped hand..." (4).

(Third) Its ruling:
The Ghamus Oath is one of the major sins. It has no expiation according to the majority of scholars, because it is an oath of deception, trickery, and lying, and the swearer has burdened himself with its sin. The Almighty said: {And do not take your oaths as [means of] deceit between you, lest a foot slip after it was [firmly] planted, and you taste evil because you averted [people] from the way of Allah, and you have a great punishment} (1).
Regarding it, the saying of Allah Almighty was revealed: {Indeed, those who exchange the covenant of Allah and their [own] oaths for a small price - they will have no share in the Hereafter, and Allah will not speak to them or look at them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them; and they will have a painful punishment} (2).
In Musnad Ahmad from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Five have no expiation: Associating partners with Allah, killing a soul without right, slandering a believer, fleeing from the battlefield, and a patient oath (Yamin Sabirah) by which wealth is appropriated without right" (3).
Ibn Masoud said: "We used to count among the sins that have no expiation the Ghamus Oath" (4).
Saeed bin Al-Musayyib said: "It is from the major sins and it is greater than to be expiated" (5). The obligation in it is repentance and returning rights to their owners.

text:
Requirement Four: Punishment of the Perjurous Oath and what entails from it in this world and the Hereafter
The Perjurous Oath (Al-Yamin Al-Fajirah) by which a Muslim appropriates his brother's wealth has effects entailed upon it, and punishments that befall its owner, some of which are immediate in this world, and some are postponed to the Day of Resurrection. I will mention them in this requirement in detail:
(First) Punishment of the Perjurous Oath and its effect on its owner in this world.
(a) The Perjurous Oath by which a Muslim appropriated his brother's wealth takes away the wealth he swore for:
Due to the Hadith of Abdul Rahman bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The perjurous oath takes away the wealth, or goes away with the wealth" (1).
(b) The Perjurous Oath is a black spot in the heart of its owner until the Day of Resurrection:
Due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Unais Al-Juhani - may Allah be pleased with him - said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "No swearer swears by Allah a patient oath (Yamin Sabr), introducing into it the weight of a mosquito's wing, except that it is made a spot in his heart until the Day of Resurrection" (2). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever appropriates the wealth of a Muslim man by a false oath, it will be a black spot in his heart that nothing changes until the Day of Resurrection" (3).
(c) The Perjurous Oath makes homes desolate and leaves them empty (Balaqi'):
In the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is nothing by which Allah is disobeyed that is swifter in punishment than oppression (Baghy), and nothing in which Allah is obeyed that is swifter in reward than maintaining ties (Silah), and the perjurous oath leaves homes empty (Balaqi')" (4). Balaqi': Plural of Balqa', which is empty land with nothing in it. He means that the swearer becomes poor and the sustenance in his house goes away. And it was said: It is that Allah scatters his affairs, and changes upon him what He bestowed upon him of blessing" (5).
In the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, also said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And indeed the swiftest disobedience in punishment is oppression and treachery, and the Ghamus Oath takes away wealth and leaves homes empty" (6).

(d) The Perjurous Oath hastens punishment for its owner in this world before the Hereafter:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever severs a kinship tie or swears a perjurous oath will see its evil consequence before he dies" (1).
(e) The Perjurous Oath's owner is stripped of blessing by the invocation of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him:
In the Hadith of Saeed bin Zaid Al-Qurashi said: I testify I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Whoever appropriates the wealth of a Muslim man by an oath, may Allah not bless him in it" (2).
(Second) Punishment of the Perjurous Oath and its effect on its owner in the Hereafter.
(a) It is among the greatest sins with Allah Almighty on the Day of Resurrection:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Ruhm Al-Sama'i said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "... And indeed among the greatest sins is one who appropriates the wealth of a Muslim man without right..." (3).
(b) The Perjurous Oath is a cause for Allah's anger upon the servant on the Day of Resurrection:
From Abdullah bin Masoud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Whoever swears a patient oath (Yamin Sabr) to appropriate by it the wealth of a Muslim man meets Allah while He is angry with him, so Allah revealed the confirmation of that: {Indeed, those who exchange the covenant of Allah and their [own] oaths for a small price - they will have no share in the Hereafter, and Allah will not speak to them or look at them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them; and they will have a painful punishment} (4). Then Al-Ash'ath bin Qais entered and said: What did Abu Abdul Rahman tell you? They said: Such and such. He said: It was revealed about me. I had a well in the land of a cousin of mine, so I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: Your evidence or his oath. I said: Then he will swear on it, O Messenger of Allah. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever swears a patient oath while he is perjurous in it to appropriate by it the wealth of a Muslim man meets Allah on the Day of Resurrection while He is angry with him" (5).
Al-Hafiz said: "It contains strictness against one who swore falsely to take the right of a Muslim, and this is unanimously interpreted as referring to one who died without valid repentance (6).

(c) The Perjurous Oath is a cause for Allah's turning away from the servant on the Day of Resurrection and not looking at him:
Due to the Hadith of Wa'il bin Hujr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: A man from Hadramaut and a man from Kinda came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. The Hadrami said: O Messenger of Allah, this man has overcome me regarding a land that belonged to my father. The Kindi said: It is my land in my hand, I farm it, he has no right in it. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to the Hadrami: Do you have evidence? He said: No. He said: "Then you have his oath". He said: O Messenger of Allah, the man is perjurous, he does not care what he swears on, and does not refrain from anything. He said: "You have nothing from him except his oath". So he went to swear. When he turned back, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If he swore on wealth to consume it unjustly, he will surely meet Allah while He is turning away from him" (1).
In the Hadith of Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Two men disputed before the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding a land, one of them from Hadramaut. He said: He assigned the oath to one of them. The other cried out and said: Then he will take my land. He said: If he appropriated it by his oath unjustly, he would be among those whom Allah does not look at on the Day of Resurrection nor purify, and he has a painful punishment. He said: The other refrained and returned it" (2).
(d) Whoever swears a perjurous oath comes on the Day of Resurrection mutilated (Ajdham):
Due to the Hadith of Al-Ash'ath bin Qais said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever swears a patient oath to appropriate by it the wealth of a Muslim man while he is perjurous in it meets Allah mutilated (Ajdham)" (3). Al-Ajdham: Is the one whose limbs are all gone. (4). And it was said Ajdham: Cut off hand, or blessing, or argument, or movement, or cut off from means.
(e) The Perjurous Oath obligates Fire for its owner and forbids him from Paradise:
In the Hadith of Abu Umama - may Allah be pleased with him - that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Whoever appropriates the right of a Muslim man by his oath, Allah has obligated the Fire for him and forbidden Paradise for him. They said: Even if it was something small, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Even if it was a twig of Arak" (5).
And from Al-Harith bin Al-Barsa', may Allah be pleased with him, said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in Hajj between the two Jamrat saying: "Whoever appropriates the wealth of his brother by a perjurous oath, let him take his seat in the Fire, let your present convey to your absent, twice or thrice" (6). And in a narration: "Let him take a house in the Fire" (7).

text:
Requirement One: Rulings related to swearing
Many rulings relate to swearing, including:
1 - It is not permissible to swear except by a name of Allah Almighty's names or an attribute of His attributes:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever has to take an oath should swear by Allah or remain silent" (1). And in a narration: "Whoever has to take an oath, let him not swear except by Allah" (2). And the oath of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was "No, and by the Turner of hearts" (3), "No, and by the Changer of hearts" (4). And in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say: "I seek refuge in Your Might" (5)
2 - Swearing by other than Allah is forbidden:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Do not swear by your fathers, nor by your mothers, nor by idols, and do not swear except by Allah..." (6). And due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever swears by other than Allah has committed Kufr or Shirk" (7). And due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Every oath sworn by other than Allah is Shirk" (8).
3 - Swearing by Allah falsely is forbidden:
Allah Almighty dispraised it in His saying: {And they swear to untruth while they know} (9). And due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever swears a perjurous oath to appropriate by it the wealth of a Muslim man meets Allah while He is angry with him" (10). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah permitted me to speak about a rooster whose legs have pierced the earth, and whose neck is bent under the Throne saying: Glory be to You, how great You are. So it is replied to it: "He does not know that who swore by Me falsely" (11).

4 - Swearing in buying and selling is disliked even if truthful:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Swearing is a mover for the goods, a remover for the blessing" (1). And due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Beware of excessive swearing in selling, for it sells then wipes out [blessing]" (2).
5 - Whoever his Muslim brother swears to him, should believe him in his oath even if he knows otherwise from him:
Due to the Hadith of Ibn Umar - may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, heard a man swearing by his father. He said: "Do not swear by your fathers, and whoever swears by Allah let him be truthful, and whoever is sworn to by Allah let him be content, and whoever is not content is not from Allah" (3).
From Abu Huraira that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Jesus son of Mary saw a man stealing, so he said: Did you steal? He said: No, by the One whom there is no god but Him. Jesus said: I believed in Allah and denied my sight" (4).
6 - Breaking oaths is forbidden, and fulfilling them (Birr) and keeping them is obligatory:
The Almighty said: {And fulfill the covenant of Allah when you have taken it, and do not break oaths after their confirmation...} (5) and prohibition implies forbiddance. And due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Swear by Allah, be righteous, and speak the truth, for Allah loves to be sworn by" (6).
7 - Introducing other than the oath into the oath is forbidden:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "No swearer swears by Allah a patient oath introducing into it the weight of a mosquito's wing except that it is made a spot in his heart until the Day of Resurrection" (7).
8 - The principle in oath is that it is on the defendant:
Due to the Hadith of Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them both - that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If people were given according to their claims, people would claim the blood of men and their wealth. But the oath is upon the defendant" (8). And in a narration in Al-Tirmidhi: "Evidence is upon the plaintiff and the oath is upon the defendant" (9).

9 - By the oath, the dispute is cut off:
Ibn al-Qayyim said, and the oath has benefits, including:
- Frightening the defendant of the bad consequence of false swearing, carrying him thereby to acknowledge the truth.
- And among them is judging against him by his refusal (Nukul) to take it.
- And among them is cutting off the dispute and demand immediately, and freeing each of the disputants from the pursuit of the other; but it does not drop the right, nor absolve the liability inwardly or outwardly. So if the plaintiff established evidence after the defendant swore, it is heard and judged by. Likewise if the oath was returned to the plaintiff and he refused, then the plaintiff established evidence, it is heard and judged by.
- And among them is establishing the right by it if it is returned to the plaintiff or he established one witness.
- And among them is hastening the punishment of the lying denier of the right upon him, for the Ghamus Oath leaves homes empty, so the oppressed becomes miserable by that instead of his oppression by losing his right, and Allah knows best (1).
10 - Oaths are built on custom:
The scholar Sayyid Muhammad Rashid Rida said: "The matter of oaths is built on the general custom among people by consensus, not on linguistic indications and Sharia terminologies. So whoever swore not to eat meat, then ate fish, does not break his oath even if Allah named it fresh meat, unless he intended it..." (2).
11 - Fulfilling the oath is prescribed if it is an act of obedience or if breaking it is not better than fulfilling it:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Hazim that Ibn Umar passed by a man with some sheep of his, so he said to him: How much do you sell these sheep for? He said: For such and such. Ibn Umar said: I take them for such and such. He swore not to sell them. Ibn Umar went and finished his need then passed by him, so he said: O Abu Abdul Rahman take them for what you gave me. He said: "I swore an oath and I would not help Satan against you by making myself break my oath" (3).
And from Abu Al-Fayd said: I heard Abdullah - a man from the people of Homs - say: I saw Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, bargaining with a man for a sheep, so he swore not to sell it, then said later: I sell it. Abu Darda said: I hate to carry you to sin, so he refused to buy it" (4).

And from Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded us to fulfill the oath of the swearer" (1).
Hinth in the oath: Breaking it and violating it, and it is as if from Ith'm (sin) and disobedience (2). And he Hanitha in his oath if he did not fulfill it (3).
12 - The rights in which the oath is permissible are:
a) "The jurists agreed on the impermissibility of swearing in purely Allah Almighty's rights, whether they are Hudud like adultery and theft... or acts of worship like prayer, fasting, and Hajj... unless a human right is attached to it, then it is permissible because Hudud are averted by doubts...".
b) And the jurists agreed - also - on the permissibility of the oath in wealth and what leads to wealth, so the defendant swears in affirmation and negation due to His saying Almighty: {Indeed, those who exchange the covenant of Allah and their [own] oaths for a small price...} (4), and due to the previous Hadith: "If people were given according to their claims, people would claim the blood of men and their wealth, but the oath is upon the defendant".
c) And the jurists agreed on the permissibility of swearing in felonies of retribution and wounds and in some issues of personal status, and differed in some of its issues..." (5).
13 - And one exits the obligation of the oath by one of three things:
First: Fulfilling it (Ibrar) by doing what was sworn upon.
Second: Expiation, and it is permissible before Hinth and after it according to verification.
Third: Exception by something like Insha'Allah - following the oath..." (6).

Requirement Two: Rulings related to the swearer
Rulings related to the swearer have been clarified by texts of the Book and Sunnah, including:
1 - He should not swear except on what he is certain of:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Al-Hawra' Al-Sa'di said: I said to Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both, what did you memorize from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "Leave what makes you doubt for what does not make you doubt, for truthfulness is tranquility and lying is doubt" (1).
2 - He should not swear that Allah will not forgive so-and-so:
Due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "There were two men from the Children of Israel who were brothers. One of them would sin, and the other exerted himself in worship. The diligent one would constantly see the other in sin; so he would say: Shorten [stop]. One day he found him on a sin, so he said to him: Shorten. He said: Leave me and my Lord; were you sent as a watcher over me? He said: By Allah, Allah will not forgive you - or Allah will not admit you to Paradise. So their souls were taken, and they gathered before the Lord of the Worlds. He said: To this diligent one, were you knowledgeable of Me or were you capable over what is in My Hand? And He said to the sinner: Go and enter Paradise by My mercy. And He said to the other: Take him to the Fire" (2).
3 - Whoever swears an oath then sees something else better than it, let him expiate for his oath and do what is better:
In the Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "... And indeed I, by Allah, if Allah wills - do not swear an oath then see something else better than it except that I do what is better and expiate it" (3).
From Abdul Rahman bin Samra said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Abdul Rahman bin Samra, do not ask for authority, for if you are given it due to asking, you will be left to it, and if you are given it without asking, you will be helped in it. And if you swore an oath then saw something else better than it, then expiate for your oath and do what is better" (4).

4 - Whoever swears not to do a matter of good should not use the oath as an excuse, but should expiate for his oath:
Due to His saying Almighty: {And do not make [your oath by] Allah an excuse against your being righteous...} (1).
Al-Shawkani said: "Meaning do not make Allah a barrier and preventer for what you swore upon. That is, a man would swear against some good like joining ties of kinship, or kindness to others, or reconciliation between people, that he will not do that, then he refrains from doing it reasoning for that refraining that he has sworn not to do it. This meaning is what the majority mentioned in interpreting the verse..." (2).
Ibn Abbas said: "A man swears not to join his kinship while Allah has made a way out for him in expiation, so He commanded him not to use Allah as an excuse, but to expiate and be righteous" (3).
5 - It is not permissible to persist in an oath if the swearer's family is harmed by it:
Due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "By Allah, for one of you to persist in his oath regarding his family is more sinful for him with Allah than to give his expiation which Allah enjoined" (4).
Al-Nawawi said "The meaning of the Hadith is that if he swears an oath relating to his family and they are harmed by his non-breaking (of the oath), and breaking it is not a sin, then he should break it and do that thing and expiate for his oath. If he says I will not break it, rather I will refrain from committing Hinth and I fear sin in it, he is mistaken in this saying. Rather, his persistence in non-breaking and continuing harm on his family is more sinful than Hinth. And Lajaj (Persistence) in language: is insisting on a thing" (5). And Lajaj is: Continuing in stubbornness in doing the action forbidden (6).
6 - Whoever swears on what he does not own or on a sin or on severing a kinship tie, has no oath and owes expiation:
Due to the Hadith of Saeed bin Al-Musayyib that two brothers from the Ansar had an inheritance between them, so one asked his companion for division. He said: If you return to ask me for division, I will never speak to you, and all my wealth is for the door/cover (Ritaj) of the Kaaba. Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Kaaba is rich without your wealth. Expiate for your oath, and speak to your brother. For I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "No oath is upon you nor vow in disobedience, nor in severing a kinship tie, nor in what you do not own" (7).
- Ritaj Al-Kaaba means: its interests or adornment (8). Abu Al-Tayyib Al-Azim Abadi said: And the meaning: binding this oath upon you is not obligatory, but expiation is upon you".

Requirement Three: General rulings
Swearing by Haram - Swearing by Divorce - Swearing the Zubayri Oath

First: Swearing by Haram:
(a) Its formula
Imam Ibn al-Qayyim _ may Allah Almighty have mercy on him _ said:
- Swearing by Haram has two formulas:
- One of them: If I do such and such, you are Haram to me, or what Allah made lawful is Haram to me.
Second: The Haram is binding on me not to do such and such" (1).
(b) Sayings of the Jurists and their evidences regarding it:
This issue was disputed by the Salaf from the Companions and Followers and the Khalaf from the Mujtahid Imams until the Scholar Al-Qurtubi the commentator counted eighteen opinions (2). Al-Hafiz said others added to them (3). Imam Ibn al-Qayyim spoke about this issue at length, reaching fifteen principal opinions branching into twenty schools (4). The closest of them are the following:
- The First Opinion: That it is vain (Laghw) and void, entailing nothing.
Ibn al-Qayyim said: It is one of the two narrations from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both. Al-Sha'bi, Masruq, Rabi'ah, Abu Salamah bin Abdul Rahman, Ata, Dawud, and all the Literalists (Ahl al-Zahir), and most of the People of Hadith said it. It is one of the two opinions of the Malikis, chosen by Asbagh bin Al-Faraj (5).
- Their Evidences:
They used as evidence His saying Almighty: (And do not say about what your tongues assert of untruth, "This is lawful and this is unlawful...") [Surah: Al-Nahl - Verse: 116]. They said: So what Allah has not made unlawful, no one has the right to make unlawful, nor does it become unlawful by his prohibition (6). And Allah said to His Prophet (7). "(... Why do you forbid what Allah has made lawful for you...)" [Surah At-Tahrim - Verse: 1].

text: And Allah addressed the believers saying: (O you who have believed, do not prohibit the good things which Allah has made lawful to you) [Surah: Al-Ma'idah - Verse: 87]. They also cited what is mentioned in Sahih Al-Bukhari (1) from Sa'id bin Jubayr that he heard Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, say: "If a man declares his wife forbidden [to himself], it is nothing. And he recited: (There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern...) [Surah Al-Ahzab - Verse: 21]." It is authentically reported from Masruq that he said: "I do not care whether I declared my wife forbidden or a bowl of Tharid (a dish)." And it is authentically reported from Al-Sha'bi regarding forbidding the wife: "It is easier to me than my sandals." Abu Salamah said: "I do not care whether I declared my wife forbidden or the water of the river forbidden" (2). - This view was preferred and supported by the scholar of Yemen, Allamah Ibn al-Amir al-San'ani. He said in Subul al-Salam: "This view is the closest of the mentioned views and the most preponderant to me..." (3). It was also preferred by Allamah Al-Shawkani in Nayl al-Awtar, who said: "And this school of thought is the preponderant one to me if he intended the prohibition of the entity itself" (4). The Second View: That it is an oath which requires the expiation of an oath in any case. Ibn al-Qayyim said: (5) "This is authentically reported from Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, Umar bin Al-Khattab, Ibn Abbas, and Aisha... and Zaid bin Thabit, Ibn Masoud, Abdullah bin Umar, Ikrimah, Ata, Makhul, Qatadah, Al-Hasan, Al-Sha'bi, Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, Sulaiman bin Yasar, Jabir bin Zaid, Sa'id bin Jubayr, Nafi', Al-Awza'i, Abu Thawr, and a multitude of others." The argument for this view: The apparent meaning of the Quran, for Allah Almighty mentioned the obligation of dissolving oaths following the prohibition of the lawful, so it must certainly cover it (6). This is in His saying, Glory be to Him: (Allah has already ordained for you [Muslims] the dissolution of your oaths...) [At-Tahrim: 2]. They also cited what is in Sahih Muslim from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "If a man forbids his wife [to himself], it is an oath which he must expiate" (7). This view was preferred by Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, and likewise by his student Ibn al-Qayyim in I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in and others (8).

text: The Third View: That it is Zihar (a specific form of divorce by equating the wife to a prohibited relative), and it requires the expiation of Zihar. Ibn al-Qayyim said (1): "This is authentically reported from Ibn Abbas as well, and Abu Qilabah, Sa'id bin Jubayr, Wahb bin Munabbih, and Uthman Al-Taymi, and it is one of the narrations from Imam Ahmad." The argument for this view is: "That Allah Almighty made likening the wife to his mother, who is forbidden to him, Zihar, and He called it a blameworthy utterance and falsehood. If likening her to a prohibited woman makes him a Muzahir (one who commits Zihar), then explicitly declaring her forbidden is more deserving of being Zihar. This is the most analogically sound and jurisprudentially deep of the views" (2). This was preferred among contemporaries by Allamah Muhammad Al-Amin Al-Shanqiti in Adwa' al-Bayan (3). The Fourth View: That it depends on his intention. If he intended divorce, it is divorce; if he intended Zihar, it is Zihar; if he intended an oath, it is an oath and requires the expiation of an oath; and if he did not intend anything, he owes the expiation of an oath (4). Ibn Hajar said: "And this was said by Al-Nakha'i, Al-Shafi'i, and Ishaq, and similar was narrated from Ibn Masoud, Ibn Umar, and Tawus (5). It is the view of Al-Zuhri, and a narration from Al-Hasan, as in Al-Fath regarding the prohibited thing: 'If he intends an oath, it is an oath; and if divorce, it is divorce'" (6). Ibn al-Qayyim said: "The argument for this view is that the wording is suitable for all of that, so one is not distinguished from the other except by intention. Also, it is a metonym (Kinayah) for divorce; if he intended it, it is divorce, and if he did not intend it, it is an oath, due to His saying: (O Prophet, why do you prohibit what Allah has made lawful for you, seeking the approval of your wives? And Allah is Forgiving and Merciful) to His saying: (...the dissolution of your oaths. And Allah is your protector, and He is the Knowing, the Wise) [At-Tahrim: 1, 2]" (7). This view is what our virtuous Sheikh, the Judge and Allamah Muhammad bin Ismail Al-Amrani, may Allah preserve him, issues fatwas based on. Scholars have many schools of thought on this issue as I mentioned previously; some considered it a revocable divorce, some considered it an irrevocable divorce, some said she is forbidden to him by virtue of his prohibition, some suspended judgment on it, and some said other than that. I have limited it to the four previous schools due to the strength of the evidence used by their proponents and because this book is built on brevity. text: Allamah Al-Qurtubi said: "Our scholars said - the reason for the disagreement in this chapter is that there is no explicit text or authentic apparent meaning in the Book of Allah or the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to rely upon in this issue, so the scholars contended over it. Those who held to the original freedom from liability said: There is no ruling; nothing is required by it. Those who said it is an oath said: Allah named it an oath. Those who said: An expiation is obligatory for it but it is not an oath, based it on two things: First, they thought Allah Almighty obligated expiation for it even if it wasn't an oath. Second, that the meaning of an oath to them is prohibition, so the expiation applied to the meaning. Those who said it is one revocable divorce interpreted the wording in its minimal sense... And likewise, the perspective of those who said it is three [divorces] interpreted it in its maximal sense, which is triple divorce... Those who said it is Zihar [did so] because it is the lowest degree of prohibition... And those who said it is an irrevocable divorce relied on the fact that revocable divorce does not prohibit the divorcee while irrevocable divorce does prohibit her..." (1). What I lean towards from the previous opinions is the fourth view, because it brings together all the other sayings and schools of thought, and because the word 'prohibition' (Tahrim) is a metonym that may mean divorce, Zihar, or an oath. Therefore, one does not turn to any of them except by intention, so acting upon the intention is necessary. This is the view our scholars issue fatwas with.

text: Second: Swearing by Divorce: It is called suspended divorce (At-Talaq Al-Mu'allaq). - It is called an oath: metaphorically by the majority of scholars because: - The condition contains the meaning of an oath, in terms of it being a clause that is not independent without the answer, so it resembled saying 'By Allah', 'By Allah', and 'By Allah'. - It was said: Because it has the ruling of an oath in terms of what it implies of urging, preventing, confirming, or denying. This issue is something many Muslims have been afflicted with, and the calamity has become widespread. "We are in a time where men have become accustomed to babbling words of divorce; making the marital bonds of their women like toys in their hands, disposing of them however they wish, respecting neither the sanctity of Sharia nor the rights of companionship..." (1). The matter of swearing by divorce is serious; indeed, it has been narrated in some traditions that it is from the oaths of the corrupt (Fusuq) (2). It is something regarding which giving fatwas arose after the end of the era of the Companions. It is an innovation introduced into the Ummah by Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi in what is called the Oaths of Allegiance (Ayman al-Bay'ah), which include swearing by Allah Almighty, divorce, manumission, and charity of wealth (3). - Its Formula: Imam Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Swearing by divorce has two formulas: - One of them: 'If you do such and such, you are divorced' - This is called the formula of suspension, i.e., suspending divorce on a condition. - The second: 'Divorce is binding upon me, I will not do such and such' (4) - This is called the formula of an oath.

text: Its Ruling: The majority of jurists agreed on the validity of the oath by divorce or suspending divorce on a condition in general (1). "Divorce was legislated by Allah Almighty for severe need, when harmony between spouses becomes impossible. Allah did not legislate it for people to misuse, nor for the rabble to make it an oath they swear by in buying, selling, and disputes. It has come in the Sahih that he, peace be upon him, said: 'Whoever swears, let him swear by Allah alone.' Thus, swearing by divorce is disliked - and it is said swearing by it is forbidden and he who swears by it should be disciplined - and according to our scholars (the Malikis), it is from the oaths of the corrupt which impugns one's integrity..." (2). - Scholars' Disagreement regarding it: Scholars from the Salaf (predecessors) and Khalaf (successors) differed on the ruling of swearing by divorce into three views, which can be elaborated along with their evidence as follows: - The First View: That whoever swears by divorce, divorce is not binding upon him - nor is expiation obligatory if he breaks it, because it is nonsense (Laghw) and void, resulting in nothing; for divorce is only as Allah Almighty commanded. This was the view of the Commander of the Faithful Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, Shuraih, Ikrimah, and Tawus. It is the school of Dawood, Ibn Hazm, and all the Zahiris (3) and others from the later scholars. Ibn Hazm said: "The oath by divorce is not binding whether fulfilled or broken; no divorce occurs by it, and there is no divorce except as Allah Almighty commanded..." (4). They reasoned that: The Commander of the Faithful Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, gave a fatwa to one who swore by divorce that he owes nothing, and no opponent from the Companions is known (5). - And it is authentic from Shuraih, the judge of the Commander of the Faithful Ali, and Ibn Masoud that divorce is not binding by it (6). - And it is authentic from Ikrimah regarding a man who said to his slave, 'If I do not whip you a hundred lashes, my wife is divorced', he said: 'He does not whip his slave and his wife is not divorced; this is from the footsteps of Satan' (7). - And it is authentic from Tawus from the narration of Abdul Razzaq from Ma'mar from Ibn Tawus from him: "Swearing by divorce is nothing" (8).

text: - They also used as evidence the saying of the Almighty: (Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths, but He will impose blame upon you for [breaking] what you intended of oaths. So its expiation is the feeding of ten needy people from the average of that which you feed your [own] families or clothing them or the freeing of a slave. But whoever cannot find [or afford it] - then a fast of three days [is required]. That is the expiation for oaths when you have sworn. But guard your oaths. Thus does Allah make clear to you His verses that you may be grateful.) [Al-Ma'idah: 89]. Ibn Hazm argued with this to show that "there is no divorce except as Allah Almighty commanded, and no oath except as Allah Almighty commanded upon the tongue of His Messenger (peace be upon him)." And the oath by divorce is not among them (1). He also used as evidence his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever swears, let him swear by Allah alone," saying "Thus the confusion is lifted that every oath by other than Allah Almighty is a sin and not a [valid] oath" (2). - Imam Al-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "As for the sayer saying 'Divorce is upon him' or 'Divorce is binding upon him', and the like, this is nothing of that sort. Allah Almighty did not make it a divorce, nor did He bind any of His servants with it. It is not valid for a servant to impose upon himself other than what Allah imposed upon him, nor to bind it with other than what Allah bound it with... In summary, there is nothing in the Sharia indicating the occurrence of this divorce, neither in wording nor in intent, so ponder this" (3). The Second View: That swearing by divorce does not cause divorce to occur, and its owner is obliged to pay the expiation of an oath unless he intended it [divorce], in which case it occurs. - This opinion was transmitted from Tawus bin Kaysan Al-Yamani, and a group of the Salaf and Khalaf said it, and some companions of Malik and Al-Shafi'i gave fatwas with it in some forms (4). It is the school of thought of Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah and his student Ibn al-Qayyim who supported it and provided evidence for it in his books. The argument of the proponents of this view: - Analogy (Qiyas): They analogized divorce to manumission. Ibn Umar, Ibn Abbas, Abu Hurairah, Aisha, Hafsa, Umm Salamah, Zainab the stepdaughter of the Prophet (peace be upon him), and more than one of the Companions gave fatwas concerning one who said 'If I do such and such, every slave I own is free,' saying he expiates for his oath and manumission is not binding upon him. This is despite manumission being an act of obedience and closeness to God, so divorce is not binding upon him by greater reason (5).

text: - They also cited what is authentically reported from Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them both - as in Al-Bukhari: "Divorce is out of need, and manumission is what is sought for the sake of Allah." The point of evidence: Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them both - clarified that divorce only occurs for one whose purpose is to effect it, not for one who dislikes its occurrence (1). They also cited what was reported from the Mother of the Believers Aisha - may Allah be pleased with her - that she said: "Every oath, even if severe, its expiation is the expiation of an oath by Allah." This covers all oaths including swearing by divorce, manumission, vows, and the like (2). - They built upon this deduction "that Allah has made an expiation for this oath where He, Glory be to Him, said: (Allah has already ordained for you the dissolution of your oaths. And Allah is your protector, and He is the Knowing, the Wise) [Surah: At-Tahrim - Verse: 2], and He said: (Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths, but He will impose blame upon you for [breaking] what you intended of oaths. So its expiation is the feeding of ten needy people from the average of that which you feed your [own] families or clothing them or the freeing of a slave. But whoever cannot find [or afford it] - then a fast of three days. That is the expiation for oaths when you have sworn. But guard your oaths. Thus does Allah make clear to you His verses that you may be grateful) [Surah: Al-Ma'idah - Verse: 89]." And it is proven from the Prophet (peace be upon him) from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, Adi bin Hatim, and Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with them, that he said: "Whoever swears an oath and then sees something else better than it, let him do that which is better and let him make expiation for his oath" (3). - As for Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, he detailed this issue and distinguished between the two formulas of swearing by divorce: The First Formula: The formula of suspension, i.e., suspending divorce on a condition, such as a man saying to his wife: 'If you leave the house without my permission, you are divorced.' The ruling for this formula according to him is "that the intention of the swearer is considered. If his intention was urging, preventing, confirming, or denying, then this is considered an oath. And if his intention was the occurrence of divorce upon her if she opposed and did what he forbade her from, then it effects a divorce if the condition is met" (4).

text: As for the Second Formula: It is the formula of an oath, such as a man saying - 'Divorce is binding upon me, I will surely do such and such' or saying 'By divorce, I will surely do such and such.' This formula is considered an oath by the agreement of linguists and the agreement of groups of jurists, but they differed in its ruling (1). Sheikh Al-Islam said: "And the most apparent of the opinions, and the opinion that agrees with the established sayings from the Companions, and is indicated by the Book, the Sunnah, and consideration, is that the expiation of an oath suffices him as in all oaths of Muslims, which is the expiation upon breaking the oath... then he said... and this is the saying of a group of the Salaf and Khalaf like Tawus and others... and many Malikis and others issue fatwas with it... and it is the implication of the texts of Ahmad bin Hanbal and his principles in more than one place..." (2). The Third View: That swearing by divorce causes divorce to occur regardless of whether he intended it or not, and whether it was suspended on a condition like 'If you enter the house you are divorced' or without suspension like 'Divorce is upon me, I will surely do such and such.' - This is the school of the majority of scholars. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: It is the famous view of most jurists and later scholars (3). They reasoned that: "Divorce is a type of forfeiture, and what is a type of forfeiture accepts suspension on a condition, like manumission, so suspending divorce is permissible. - Also, divorce is a legal disposition whether immediate or suspended, so it must be fulfilled because it falls under the scope of the noble verse: 'O you who have believed, fulfill [your] obligations...'. - Also, he committed to a matter upon the existence of a condition, so what he committed to is binding upon him because the conditional is like the immediate upon the existence of the condition, so it falls under the scope of the noble Prophetic Hadith which says 'Muslims are bound by their conditions except a condition that makes the lawful unlawful or the unlawful lawful' (4) and suspending divorce on a condition is not making the unlawful lawful or the lawful unlawful (5). - It is said in Al-Durr Al-Mukhtar: "And among the used phrases are 'Divorce is binding upon me', 'The unlawful is binding upon me', 'Upon me is divorce', and 'Upon me is the unlawful'; so it occurs without intention due to custom" (6).

text: - It is said in Al-Mudawwanah: "The view that suspended divorce occurs has been transmitted with authentic chains from a group of Companions, from the general jurists of the Tabi'in, from the seven famous jurists of Medina, and from the majority of jurists after them, including the four Imams. Only a small group of scholars disagreed with it, having no reliable basis for their disagreement except a fatwa by Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, despite the probability in its indication regarding non-occurrence" (1). What I consider preponderant: After this presentation of the scholars' views and their evidence, is the school of the majority of scholars. - So whoever suspends divorce on a condition, divorce occurs upon the realization of the condition for the following reasons: - 1 - Because the conditional is like the immediate upon the existence of the condition (2). 2 - Because the principle regarding sexual relations is prohibition, so one should take the more cautious path in matters of divorce, and be pious regarding them, so that those who are lenient do not dare violate the limits of Allah and play with them. The Almighty said: (And do not take the verses of Allah in jest) [Surah: Al-Baqarah - Verse: 231]. - In Sunan Al-Nasa'i from the Hadith of Mahmud bin Labid, he said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was informed about a man who divorced his wife three times all at once. He stood up angry and said: Is the Book of Allah being played with while I am among you? Until a man stood up and said: O Messenger of Allah, shall I kill him?" (3). If the Prophet, peace be upon him, considered the one who divorces his wife three times at once to be playing with the Book of Allah, then how about the one who makes divorce his habit in all his affairs? - Imam Ibn Abidin said in his Hashiyah quoting Al-Saruji: "I say the truth is [divorce] occurs by it in this time due to its fame in the meaning of divorce, so it must be referred to and relied upon, acting on precaution in the matter of private parts" (4). 3 - Deterring the one swearing by divorce: The Commander of the Faithful Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, when he saw people's haste in the matter of divorce, enforced it upon them as three. In Sahih Muslim from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: "Divorce during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, and two years of the caliphate of Umar was [counted as] one for the three [pronouncements]. Then Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: People have hastened in a matter in which they had respite; so if we were to enforce it upon them! So he enforced it upon them" (5).

text: "So the Muslim must fear Allah Almighty regarding himself and not swear by divorce nor by anything else which the Lawgiver forbade swearing by, because swearing by divorce exposes the marital bond to destruction. Indeed, some scholars mentioned that the one who does it cannot be secure about his wife remaining with him, for she might be in [a state of] adultery due to his frequent swearing. This is what Ibn Mayaba versified saying: - And frequent swearing by divorce ... * ... Is immorality and a defect necessitating separation. Whatever is like that must be warned against and avoided" (1). "Finally, I advise you, my brother, not to make divorce a chewed item in your mouth. If you want to emphasize and urge yourself or your wife to do something or prevent it, then swear an oath by Allah Almighty, for divorce was not legislated in the law of Islam to emphasize news or to urge or prevent" (2).

text: Third: Swearing the Zubayri Oath: The Zubayri oath is an oath that some still use to make people swear. It is believed that whoever swears it falsely is swiftly punished. I will write about it as follows: - A) Its formula: - That the swearer be told to say: "I have disavowed the power and strength of Allah and sought refuge in my own power and strength, and assumed power and strength without Allah, out of arrogance against Allah, dispensing with Him and exalting myself over Him, if I said such and such or did such and such..." B) The first to make someone swear by it: - It was Imam Yahya bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. Abdullah bin Mus'ab Al-Zubayri swore by it when he slandered him to Al-Rashid, claiming he wanted the Caliphate instead of him. C) The reason for making someone swear by it: There is a story for making someone swear this oath mentioned by historians like Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari, Ibn Kathir, and others. Its summary is: - That Yahya bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, appeared in the land of Daylam during the time of Harun Al-Rashid. His power intensified, his command grew strong, and people traveled to him from the regions. Al-Rashid was greatly distressed and anxious about his affair. He assigned Al-Fadl bin Yahya bin Khalid bin Barmak with fifty thousand men and senior commanders to go to him. Al-Fadl marched to that region and wrote to Yahya bin Abdullah promising him, raising his hopes, and assuring him that if he came out to him, he would provide an excuse for him to Al-Rashid. Yahya refused to come out to them until Al-Rashid wrote a letter of safety (Aman) for him by his own hand on a copy sent to him. Al-Fadl wrote this to Al-Rashid, and Al-Rashid rejoiced and it had a great impact on him. He wrote the safety by his hand and had judges, jurists, and the elders of Banu Hashim witness it. He sent it with prizes and gifts. Al-Fadl sent that to him, so Yahya bin Abdullah arrived, and Al-Fadl arrived with him in Baghdad. Al-Rashid met him with everything he liked, ordered much wealth for him, gave him generous gifts, and the Barmakids served him greatly. Then Al-Rashid turned against Yahya bin Abdullah and changed towards him. It is said he imprisoned him then summoned him while groups of Hashimites were present. He brought the safety he had sent to him. Al-Rashid asked Muhammad bin Al-Hasan the jurist, the companion of Abu Yusuf: Is this safety valid? He said yes. Al-Rashid became angry with him. Then he asked Abu Al-Bakhtari, who said: This is void from such and such perspective and this is nothing, so judge regarding it as you wish, and Abu Al-Bakhtari tore the safety and spat on it. Al-Rashid said: You are the Judge of Judges and you know best about that. Slanderers had spread gossip between Al-Rashid and Yahya bin Abdullah. Whenever Al-Rashid softened towards him, they stirred up malice in his soul against him. They mentioned that Yahya said to Al-Rashid: O Commander of the Faithful, we have kinship
foot_note: None

text: and mercy... We and you are people of one house, so I remind you of Allah regarding our kinship to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, why do you imprison me and torture me? Harun softened towards him. Abdullah bin Mus'ab Al-Zubayri, who was the governor of Medina during the days of Al-Rashid, said to him: O Commander of the Faithful, do not let the speech of this one deceive you, for he is a rebellious dissenter. This is only deception and malice from him. He has corrupted our city against us and manifested disobedience in it. Yahya replied to him, and among what he said was: O Commander of the Faithful, this one came to me when my brother Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan was killed and said: May Allah curse his killer, and recited to me about twenty verses of poetry. And he said to me: If you move in this matter, I will be the first to pledge allegiance to you. What prevents you from joining Basra when our hands are with you? Al-Zubayri's face changed and he denied it and began swearing solemn oaths that he was lying about that. Al-Rashid was confused, then said to Yahya: Do you memorize anything of the elegy? He said: Yes, and recited part of it to him: - Rise with your command, we will rise with our obedience ** The Caliphate is among you, O sons of Hasan. Al-Zubayri increased in denial and said: By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, besides Whom there is no god... until he reached the end of the Ghamus (false) oath, nothing of what he said happened. Al-Rashid turned to Yahya and said: He has sworn. Do you have evidence who heard this elegy from him? He said: No, O Commander of the Faithful, but make him swear by what I want. He said: Make him swear. He turned to Al-Zubayri and said: Say: If I am lying, I disavow the power and strength of Allah and seek refuge in my own power and strength, and assume power and strength without Allah, out of arrogance against Allah, dispensing with Him and exalting myself over Him, if I said it. Al-Zubayri refused to swear by that. Al-Rashid insisted and got angry at him, so he swore by it. No sooner had he left Al-Rashid's presence than Allah struck him with hemiplegia (paralysis) and he died instantly. Then Al-Rashid released Yahya bin Abdullah and gave him one hundred thousand dinars. It is said he only imprisoned him for part of a day, and it is said three days. He lived after all that for one month then died, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him (1).
